page.title: 11A LOCAL CHARACTER
page.content: In the last century, there lived in Lillington a poor road scraper called William Treen. As he worked around the area, he would beg kitchen scraps from the farmers wives. Back in his little cottage these turnip tops, cabbage leaves and the like went into his pot to make the thin soup on which he lived. The local people felt very sorry for poor old Billy. When he died, however,a hoard of gold was found in the cottage, and local sympathy evaporated. The angry villagers erected a gravestone which still stands. In memory of 'William Treen the miserd',it bears a short verse: I poorly lived and poorly died, Poorly buried and no one cried.
